<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_try_map:
```c
static int metal_shmem_try_map(struct metal_page_size *ps, int fd, size_t size,
			       struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	size_t pages, page, phys_size;
	struct metal_io_region *io;
	metal_phys_addr_t *phys;
	uint8_t *virt;
	void *mem;
	int error;

	size = metal_align_up(size, ps->page_size);
	pages = size / ps->page_size;

	error = metal_map(fd, 0, size, 1, ps->mmap_flags, &mem);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
			  "failed to mmap shmem %ld,0x%x - %s\n",
			  size, ps->mmap_flags, strerror(-error));
		return error;
	}

	error = mlock(mem, size);
	if (error) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "failed to mlock shmem - %s\n",
			  strerror(errno));
	}

	phys_size = sizeof(*phys) * pages;
	phys = malloc(phys_size);
	if (!phys) {
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	io = malloc(sizeof(*io));
	if (!io) {
		free(phys);
		metal_unmap(mem, size);
		return -ENOMEM;
	}

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0) {
		phys[0] = 0;
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
		"shmem - failed to get va2pa mapping. use offset as pa.\n");
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, -1, 0, &metal_shmem_io_ops);
	} else {
		for (virt = mem, page = 0; page < pages; page++) {
			size_t offset = page * ps->page_size;

			error = metal_virt2phys(virt + offset, &phys[page]);
			if (error < 0)
				phys[page] = METAL_BAD_OFFSET;
		}
		metal_io_init(io, mem, phys, size, ps->page_shift, 0,
			&metal_shmem_io_ops);
	}
	*result = io;

	return 0;
}
```

explanation:
I flagged fragments where pointer types are declared or passed and where adding a const qualifier to the pointed-to type might be appropriate (parameters and local pointer variables, pointer arithmetic and calls that pass those pointers). I did not flag other fragments because:
- phys is written to (phys[page] = ...), so the array elements cannot be const in this function; investigation of a const qualification on the called function's parameter (if it only reads the array) would be external to this function.
- result is used to return a newly allocated pointer (*result = io), so the function must write through the pointer; the pointed-to object cannot be const here.
- io and the memory region (mem) are allocated/initialized and intended to be mutable by callers; making those pointers point to const would prevent necessary usage.
- Calls that take output parameters (metal_map with &mem, metal_virt2phys with &phys[page]) require non-const targets since they are written by the callees.
- Other local uses of pointers that mutate data or are used as outputs were therefore not included because const qualification would be inappropriate.
